race.name: TOUR DE NEBRASKA
race.tagline: Five days of supported gravel cruising through Nebraska's rolling farmland - more family reunion than race, and that's exactly the point

vitals.elevation_note: Rolling terrain, estimated total across 5 days

logistics.explanation: Southwest Nebraska is remote - McCook sits 284 miles from Omaha (4.5 hour drive). However, the tour handles camping, luggage transport between sites, and daily SAG support, reducing individual logistics burden. Sandy H. calls it "one of the most enjoyable bike tours in the Midwest" partly due to the seamless organization.

length.explanation: Daily distances of 35-59 miles are modest by gravel standards. The tour prioritizes accessibility with a "no schedules, no deadlines" philosophy and minimum 10 mph pace requirement. While the 5-day total exceeds 250 miles, per-day mileage fits in the recreational range rather than endurance athlete territory. More compact than Grinduro.

technicality.explanation: Mostly maintained gravel roads suitable for various bike types. The optional gravel adventure includes single-lane minimum maintained roads (MMRs) and fresh gravel sections. Rosa Kloser noted "Due to the SRAM Transmission system, I could push it in the mud without losing the derailleur" during challenging sections, but routes remain intentionally accessible. Less technical than The Mid South.

elevation.explanation: JOM discovered "there were 87 hills along the full 150-mile course" in the region, noting "they don't hold the remotest flicker of a candle to the hills of Lincoln, Nebraska." Koalb describes the terrain: "You're going to be up and down over the whole course. None of the climbs are that big, but there are a ton of them." Less climbing than The Mid South.

climate.explanation: June brings serious weather challenges in Nebraska. KCBikeNerd reported "Heat index was 105+. Omg it was so hot" during a recent event. The 2018 race saw 88°F temperatures with unexpected humidity levels. June is peak thunderstorm season with tornado risk and constant wind exposure on open plains. Similar climate challenges to SBT GRVL.

altitude.explanation: Southwest Nebraska sits around 2,500-3,000 feet elevation. No altitude acclimatization needed - sea level fitness transfers directly. This is pure Great Plains riding with no high-altitude factors affecting performance or preparation. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds — no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: The gravel adventure explores single-lane maintenance roads through Nebraska farmland, but this remains a supported tour rather than epic adventure. Matt Beers described mud sections where "I had to bridge up through three groups" after getting caught out, adding some challenge to otherwise pastoral rolling terrain.

prestige.explanation: Sandy H. calls it "one of the most enjoyable bike tours in the Midwest" with 4.7-star rider satisfaction, but it's overshadowed by Gravel Worlds in the gravel scene. Recognition remains primarily within the Nebraska cycling community despite 37 years of operation and exceptional organization.

race_quality.explanation: Exceptional organization with 37 years of refinement. Testimonials consistently praise the operation: "This was the most expertly organized ride we've ever been on! The friendly, accommodating crew, fun breweries, good food and gorgeous camping spots were second to none!" Rest stops every 15 miles, SAG support, shower trucks, luggage transport - professional-grade tour operation.

experience.explanation: The "big rolling family reunion" atmosphere creates memorable experiences through small-town Nebraska hospitality. One rider noted: "I enjoy the camaraderie among cyclists. It's always fun to see familiar faces and catch up, and I love that I meet interesting people whose paths I'd never have crossed otherwise."

community.explanation: This is the standout dimension. Capped at 500 riders specifically "which allows for meaningful interaction between riders and the quaint communities we visit." Strong repeat rider base creates actual friendships. "Sharing the joys and the miseries of long rides brings people together" - the explicit purpose is connection over competition.

field_depth.explanation: Explicitly "not a race, it's a tour" with no categories, officials, or prize money. Minimum 10 mph pace requirement attracts recreational cyclists and first-timers. The gravel adventure is limited to just 30 spots as an optional add-on rather than competitive field depth. Thinner field than Ouray Gravel Grinder.

value.explanation: Five days of fully supported riding with camping, SAG support, shower trucks, luggage transport, meals, and rest stops included. Student discounts available. For a multi-day supported tour, the included amenities represent solid value.

expenses.explanation: Registration costs undisclosed but multi-day supported tours typically run $300-500+. Food budget ~$250 additional for 5 days. The 284-mile drive from Omaha adds significant travel cost, though camping reduces lodging expense. Total weekend cost falls in moderate $500-1k range for supported touring. Similar expense level to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

distances.name: 5-Day Tour
distances.description: Multi-day supported tour across Southwest Nebraska with optional gravel adventure component

distances.name: Gravel Adventure
distances.description: Single-lane maintenance roads and fresh gravel sections for gravel enthusiasts

race.terrain: Mix of paved roads and gravel; optional gravel adventure includes single-lane maintenance roads, fresh gravel, and minimum maintenance roads (MMR)
race.registration: Limited to 500 riders (main tour), 30 spots for Gravel Adventure; opens on BikeReg with early registration discounts
race.weather: June Nebraska - highs 81-85F, potential for 100F+ heat, thunderstorm season, tornado risk, constant wind, June is wettest month
uniqueCharacteristics: Multi-day supported tour (5 days) - NOT a race
Capped at 500 riders for community feel
Optional Gravel Adventure limited to 30 spots
Fully supported: SAG, shower trucks, luggage transport, rest stops every 15 miles
Circle tour format - start and end in same town
Small-town Nebraska hospitality and community focus
Suitable for various bike types including road bikes and e-bikes
First-timer friendly with 10 mph minimum pace
race.popularity: Regional favorite - loyal repeat rider community

final_verdict.one_liner: Nebraska's genteel summer camp for cyclists who want gravel adventure without the gravel commitment.
final_verdict.should_you_race: Perfect for riders wanting to dip their toes into multi-day touring without the suffer-fest. The main tour welcomes any bike and fitness level, while the 30-rider gravel component offers real Nebraska dirt roads for those ready to upgrade. Skip if you need competition or epic single climbs—this is about rolling hills, beer at camp, and discovering that Nebraska isn't actually flat.
final_verdict.alternatives: Gravel Worlds in Lincoln delivers the full Nebraska gravel experience with actual racing, while RAGBRAI offers similar supported touring with bigger crowds and more chaos. If you want the multi-day format but harder terrain, look at Dirty Kanza's multi-day events.

course_description.character: Tour de Nebraska is gravel touring disguised as vacation—250 miles of rolling Nebraska farmland where the wind never stops and the hills never quit. Five days of single-lane maintenance roads and well-worn dirt paths that look innocent on paper but grind you down with relentless undulation. The optional gravel adventure component turns those pastoral country roads into proper suffering, especially when fresh gravel meets crosswinds on exposed ridgelines.

suffering_zones.label: Curtis to Elwood Reality Check
suffering_zones.desc: Day one's 41 miles introduce you to Nebraska's signature lie—there are no flat roads here, just constant rolling resistance. The wind finds every exposed section and reminds you this isn't Kansas.

suffering_zones.label: Cambridge Approach Grind
suffering_zones.desc: Day two's gravel adventure component kicks in with single-lane maintenance roads that look manageable until you hit the sandy sections. Your 35mm tires start feeling optimistic.

suffering_zones.label: McCook Marathon
suffering_zones.desc: Day three's 59-mile push to McCook includes the challenging climbs along Middle Creek Road and West Lake Drive. Hill after hill with no recovery, just Nebraska's version of death by a thousand cuts.

suffering_zones.label: Optional Loop Punishment
suffering_zones.desc: The 56-mile optional loop on day four separates tourists from masochists. Fresh gravel sections combined with accumulated fatigue make this the course's hidden knife.

suffering_zones.label: Curtis Homecoming Crawl
suffering_zones.desc: The final 40 miles back to Curtis feel longer than the previous four days combined. Your legs know they're supposed to be done, but Nebraska's rolling terrain has other plans.

course_description.signature_challenge: The relentless undulation combined with Nebraska's ever-present wind creates a grinding war of attrition that looks deceptively easy on elevation profiles. It's not the climbs that break you—it's the fact that the road never actually flattens, the wind never stops, and over 250 miles those constant rollers compound into serious suffering.

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

primary.name: Vittoria Terreno Mix
primary.why: Graphene versatility. Mixed-terrain grip with reasonable rolling speed.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners
